body: thanks @sirpkt, results seem good. üëç, this looks good to be merged after @gianm comments are addressed.
üëç  LGTM, thanks @sirpkt
since this is one of the last few PRs for 0.9.2, as discussed on the call last week, I'll bump it to 0.9.3.
üëç  LGTM, thanks for the updates @dclim

@pjain1 yes that seems good to me, sorry for missing your comment; logic looks good to me, maybe just ensure the Kafka consumer gets cleaned up if start() fails which is something I should've done before, thanks!
@navis i meant some not same sorry !
@dclim added please verify
nishantmonu51 , thanks.
@pjain1 sweet thanks, LGTM üëç
rebased with master
üëç
we should do this for 0.9.2, right? I don't think we want snapshot dependencies in the release.
@himanshug gonna change it, but if I'm missing something let me know.
@gianm sure, had put wrong milestone by mistake... it will be needed before we do the 0.9.2 cut.
thanks! üëç
LGTM üëç

I removed the endpoint at coordinator.
@drcrallen Does it make sense to add local storage information in `HistoricalMetricsMonitor`?
Squashed and merged with #2820, caused by hard-maintenance for long abandoned time.
@b-slim Addressed comments
Rebased to master

@drcrallen You're right. `currSize` is updated during loadLocalCache().  I'd better to close this issue.

However, I'll keep #3445 because `SegmentLoaderLocalCacheManager` still has some impovement points that I think.
- When user specifies multiple paths on the same partition by mistake, it will induce skewed disk usage on that server. Actually I experienced that situation.
- Other applications may share the same disk with historical nodes, so user may not use the amount of disk specified by `maxSize`. It needs to monitor disk usage and update possible maximum size.
we need to add this flag to IndexTask also ?
looks good to me after https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2282#discussion_r79800599

I tried it out and it only works when : 
1) not specifying `--updateDescriptor` flag
2) specifying `--updateDescriptor true`

But if you specify : 
1) `--updateDescriptor false`
2) `--updateDescriptor "false"`

Then it throws : 

```
ERROR!!!!
Found unexpected parameters: [false]
===
usage: druid <command> [<args>]
```

But I suspect this is a problem of the argument parser, not this particular extension. Any idea? Imho currently one can use this only when updating descriptor is enabled
üëç
üëç
I totally didn't mean to push this to a druid-io branch, sorry about that.

Thanks for the contribution!

Could you please fill out our project CLA here and post when that's done? http://druid.io/community/cla.html
@gianm doh, you beat me to it. I'll retract my comment :)
Wow you guys are fast. I've just submitted the CLA üëç
@Fokko small patch, obvious fix, new contributor, properly formatted... all those things make it nice and easy.
üëç for new changes

@jaehc I must be doing something wrong, I have : 
- s3 deep storage after an old druid cluster 
- I run this `insert-segment-to-db` tool to fill Mysql with the segments from it
- I start the new historical node and it is loading and dropping segments indefinitely

Look, this is a `grep` of a single index : 

```
gwiq-s_2016-01-25T00:00:00.000Z_2016-01-26T00:00:00.000Z_2016-08-30T17:10:33.169Z
```

http://pastebin.com/raw/HSkNt71E

This is a single sequence : 
http://pastebin.com/raw/h6DQiKj2

I cannot make any sense out of it. The rules for the data source are : 

```
load Forever `2` in `_default_tier`
```

Nothing else, what reason does it have for dropping the segments ?

@navis i was working on a separate task which needed something similar and I was doing a bit differently, by taking multiple locks one per dataSource. please see https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3482 .

can the change there fulfill your need? or else I will see how it can be changed so that both use cases can be supported.

@gianm can you please check this. I am not sure about the inject stuff if such class should be only created by Jackson or it is ok to have the `@Inject` annotation. BTW there is a small bug about the cache as well.

Guys I think that it is a bug in the `insert-segment-to-db` tool, it doesn't respect segment versions and it loads all of them, details in here : 
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/druid-user/Q0L4obz2jtc
Implemented in #3484

I just upgraded to `0.9.1.1` and after stopping graphite and starting again, I can see 3 more of these in middleManager logs : 

```
2016-09-22T00:29:03,515 ERROR [GraphiteEmitter-1] io.druid.emitter.graphite.GraphiteEmitter - Broken pipe
java.net.SocketException: Broken pipe
    at java.net.SocketOutputStream.socketWrite0(Native Method) ~[?:1.8.0_101]

    at java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call(Executors.java:511) [?:1.8.0_101]

    at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745) [?:1.8.0_101]
```

So I'm afraid it still happens, I have to restart middleManager for emitter to connect again.
@himanshug thanks for notifying me. imho, #3482 incurs too much changes and too complicated for our simple use cases. I'll close this but we seemed to stick to this.
failed `io.druid.server.lookup.PollingLookupTest` which seemed not related to this.
@navis https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/3480
Rebased on master and now it supports excel types and takes Map<String, Object> as parameter.

@l15k4 
About `updateDescriptor`, It appears that a boolean variable does not take an argument in Airline. So I've turned the type of the variable into a string and cast it to a boolean.

The message for me was different with  https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3476#issuecomment-248710267

@drcrallen would it be worth putting this in 0.9.2 or should we hold this until that branch is cut?
closing & reopening for travis
All review comments seem handled, changed milestone to 0.9.2.

Closing.
The problem was because of shading Guava.
I don't know how to solve it with hadoop 2.6.0 but hadoop-client 2.7.1 works fine with 2.6.0 cluster and can be compiled with guava 16.

@jaehc Regarding loading all segments, imho it's not an improvement but a bug :-) I wouldn't merge this until it is resolved, first of all it creates an infinite loop of  LOADing and DROPing segments and secondly I can't imagine anyone who wouldn't mind having old segment versions get mixed up into new ones.

But I agree that it should be in another PR... Imho one should submit KillTask for all unused segments and stop Coordinator after that ... or having `druid.coordinator.kill` do it...

Fixed a missing case when converting google segments. And again rebased on master.

And I back ported this branch to 0.9.1.1
See: https://github.com/erikdubbelboer/druid/tree/0.9.1.1-google-extensions
For people who want to try these changes with 0.9.1.1 here are my build artifacts:
https://www.atomx.com/druid-0.9.1.1-bin.tar.gz
https://www.atomx.com/druid-google-extensions-0.9.1.1.jar

Test failing has nothing to do with this pull.
üëç

write and rename seems to be the only reasonable way to do anything these days :)
üëç
since there are no updates on this PR and this is the last 0.9.2 PR blocking the release,I have created https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3494 with additional commits for review comments.
:+1: ( waiting for build )

@pjain1 this is in can you do the follow up PR for 0.9.2 ?
rebased and resolved conflict
üëç

@pjain1 have you seen this issue while shutting down a supervisor? I considered this possibility but I think that in most cases the shutdown logic should take less than 15 seconds unless the tasks are for some reason not very responsive (and there was an issue around this but #3401 should have fixed it)

Hmm, with graceful shutdowns, it's always good for there to be a timeout after which we give up and stop things forcefully. You never know when something will be stuck and not shutting down for some unforeseen reason, like a hardware problem, network problem, or a bug.
üëç

@pjain1 what if we made the supervisor shutdown timeout configurable + increased the default value, would that help alleviate the concern? That would allow users to set the timeout to something that makes sense for them while still retaining the hard kill to ensure that the supervisor doesn't leave any hung threads lying around

Yes, I think that should work. FYI, here's the log -

@pjain1 okay cool I'll make the change

Interesting, any idea why the tasks were taking so long to pause (anything in the task logs)? Were they in the middle of a persist to disk?

yes they were persisting and it took some time for them to finish the persist.  Will they not respond to commands from supervisor when they are persisting ? Isn't that persist happens in a separate thread ?

@pjain1 hmm yeah, I believe if the persists are taking too long, and maxPendingPersists is exceeded, ingestion will be throttled, the run loop will block, and the pause command won't be handled immediately until the next run loop cycle.
@pjain1 let me know if this works for you guys
I see.. I think that's what I am running into. Thanks for the clarification.

@pjain1 if #3484 is approved, you should be able to use the /reset endpoint followed immediately by a /shutdown to accomplish the force kill of running tasks and shutting down of the supervisor (if you're okay with the metadata being cleared out also)
Same issue occurring to me
Have there been any updates to this?
üëç  LGTM

NICE!

> > but it was not enough for our use case
> > Perhaps the following issue https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/3202 applies to your use case as well?
@gianm got some complaints on `"ordering" : {"type":"myComparator"}`. so we've decided to use this :)
@l15k4 It is such a great finding. I agree that it should be fixed in another PR. Do you feel like to handle it later on by yourself?
@jaehc I just migrated whole production cluster to new one, I'd be happy to do that when I need it again so I can test it...
hey @pjain1, if you have a chance to review this we can try to get it into the 0.9.2 RC

@dclim configurable timeout looks good to me however I was wondering if we need to kill the tasks in case of a timeout as it may happen that supervisor may not get change to resume the tasks and those tasks will never finish. What do you think ?

@pjain1 that makes sense to me, probably if they haven't responded by the timeout they're not in the best of states and we don't expose the chat handler endpoints for the task so all the user would be able to do anyway is to kill it manually; @gianm any concerns?

Killing tasks that the supervisor believes to be in a bad state is probably a good idea.

The worst that can happen is a rogue supervisor killing tasks inappropriately, although we could address that in the future with some epoch stuff. Even without that, though, I think the benefits of killing nonresponsive tasks outweigh the risks.
btw, by "some epoch stuff" I mean #3498.

@pjain1 to kill the tasks properly after the timeout (basically logic to avoid killing tasks that have already started publishing) requires a little more invasive changes than I first thought; could I post those changes in another PR so that this one can get in sooner?
@dclim IMO it's fine to do that in a different PR

actually, your comment about avoiding killing tasks that are publishing makes me wonder: what kind of supervisor shutdown are we talking about here?

If it's a shutdown that is actually a restart, where we expect the supervisor to come back at some point, then it's probably better to not kill tasks at all. The new supervisor can do that if it wants to. If it's a shutdown that is meant to be final, I'm comfortable with killing tasks that are publishing. We want ingestion to stop, and it shouldn't really be useful to let publishing tasks finish.

So it seems to me that there may not be any cases where we want to treat publishing tasks specially. Unless I'm missing something.
üëç
Fixed by https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3494

I think it's a mistake, API-wise, to conflate "shutdown" and "flush". If we want to satisfy that use case¬†you mentioned, we could introduce a "flush" API. This has a few advantages over combining them:
- callers that want to shutdown quickly without flushing data can just call "shutdown", and all inflight data will be dropped
- callers that want to flush data and then shutdown supervising can call "flush" followed by "shutdown" after all the data is flushed (which I guess the caller would check with some other API).
- avoids the awkward question of: if someone calls "shutdown" and that waits for tasks to publish, what happens if a task fails? Really, we should respawn it, or else this isn't a very useful API for people that want to load a batch of data and then shutdown. But respawning tasks during shutdown mode is a bit strange and can delay shutdown by quite some time‚Ä¶

Similarly it's probably also a mistake to conflate "shutdown forevers" and "shutdown for the purposes of restarting soon". For the first probably the best experience is to nuke all inflight data, for the latter we definitely don't want to do that.
